captions.text:
As a kid you learn all about the cool
and awesome parts of space
exploration.

About moon walks and docking with the
soviets and the heroing tale of
Apollo 13

but for some reason you don't hear
 nearly as much about going to
the bathroom in space.

-Actually Henry
I can tell you about it

This right here is the Apollo 16
command module.

and I'm going to tell you about how they
pooped in space.

I am at the US space and rocket center, 
and this is
a fecal collection assembly.

Its basically a plastic bag that
astronauts
would tape to their butt.

-Alright so, 
number 2 in a cramped sealed, 
command module with
"sounds" like fun...
Well what about number 1?
Well. The urine transfer system

was basically a rubbery condom 
attached to a metal tube
which you could either
connect to a bag, or through a
differential pressure valve so you
could pee directly into space.

So this, is what hooks you up
to space.

Todo lo que te protege es
esta válvula
This/
You/ Valve / Outer Space
Just think about that for a second.
-I think I might pass...

which is actually what that yellow bag
is for

so you can pee first
and dump it into space later
-That port is where the urine came out

and if you think about it, anything your
throwing off your spacecraft

is gonna change the trajectory of
your spacecraft

-In the case of a few hundred
milliliters
of urine and a
45,000Kg space craft, you might only

change the velocity of your craft by a
few hundredths
of a km/h, on a 3 day trip to the moon

thats enough to where you have to let
mission control know when you stop

to use the facilutys
and once your on the moon

collecting moon rocks, well.. the lunar
module's ascent stage only

has enough fuel to carry
a few hundred
pounds of extra weight.

-So here's my question. So if I  
had the option to take my poop,
put it in this bag.

Would I rather bring this back in the
acsent stage, or a moon rock.

-The choice is clear! At least, it was
to the apollo astronauts.

In jedessine bags like this one
the astronauts left a lot of stuff on
the moon.

drills, baterries, food containers
and towels
and cameras

moon boots and,
there it is.

Poop. There are no who ways about it
when
the astronauts left their poop,
on the moon.

By the way, NASA has
the space toilet figured out at this
time.
So lets move from this bathroom humour.

-Actually Henry, are you OK with me
hangin' out with some of your viewers
in the bathroom a little longer

I'm gonna explain an experiment that
is still on the moon.
That I only think
about when I go to the bathroom

It still works, too. So, any of you guys
wanna come? Come on, click here.
This was filmed on the actual

moon right now.
-Yeah it rained earlier today
on the moon.

- So we are breaking the seal on a 60
year-old urine transfer bag.

We keep it here at the museum at the
US space and rocket center.
No way...
This is like the most intimate piece
its made by whirlpool.
[laughs]

comments.author: Christopher Rowland

comments.text:
So... the moon I can kind of understand, since it's too harsh for the 
organisms that live in our gut to really survive, but what about Mars? 
We're not really expecting to find life on the Moon at this point anyhow. 
But there's already been some concern about the possible bacterial 
contamination of Mars by earlier space rovers and probes. If we're looking 
to find potential life up there, or evidence of past life, it's probably 
not going to be a good idea to leave big bags of festering bacterial 
colonies littered around the Martian landscape when we finally send people 
there.﻿

comments.author: grandpaJoeWCG

comments.text:
+Victoria FitzGibbon
It... wouldn't do either of those things. It'd just get very, very, very 
cold - and then probably die and have to be surgically removed. I'm not 
even sure if it would force an evacuation of your bladder, but certainly it 
would cause all of the moisture and fluids inside the urethra to boil since 
they're no longer under pressure. This processes will happen inside the 
exposed blood vessels as well, and while it won't cause them to "explode", 
it could cause embolisms (gas bubbles in your blood and tissues).

I mean, you're only going from really 1 atmosphere of pressure to 0. 
Compare this to the diving bell accident on the Byford Dolphin oil rig back 
in 1983. They were under 9 atmospheres of pressure, which released almost 
instantly back to 1 atmosphere, killing all four divers inside. Only one of 
them "exploded" in any sense, and that was because he was right next to the 
hatch between the Bell and Decompression chamber where the pressure 
gradient was highest. He was basically liquified and squeezed out the crack 
of the door as it opened.

comments.author: TheNiceJoffrey

comments.text:
If they left poop on the moon, it means that there is now life on the moon. 
Poop contain a lot of bacteria. Here I quote Kenneth Todar, PhD : "The 
flora of the large intestine (colon) is qualitatively similar to that found 
in feces. Populations of bacteria in the colon reach levels of 10^11/ml 
feces. Coliforms become more prominent, and enterococci, clostridia and 
lactobacilli can be regularly found, but the predominant species are 
anaerobic Bacteroides and anaerobic lactic acid bacteria in the genus 
Bifidobacterium (Bifidobacterium bifidum)"

So, yes, there are now dormant bacteria on the moon :)﻿

comments.author: goodpower ofwill

comments.text:
That's just the landing shuttle.  If you pause at 1:24, you can see the 
main parts of the Apollo craft.  The bullet-shaped part on the left is the 
Command/Service Module (CSM).  One astronaut stays there while the other 
two land and have their fun on the Moon.  For Apollo 11, Neil Armstrong and 
"Buzz" Aldrin landed while Michael Collins stayed in orbit.

The spider-looking thing on the right is the Lunar Module (LM), which 
detaches and goes down to the lunar surface.  When Armstrong and Aldrin 
were done, the ball part broke away from the legs and launched as you saw 
at 2:06.  A few minutes later they met back up with Collins, they all got 
into the CSM, they ditched what was left of the LM (it's presumed to have 
crashed a few months later) and they came home.
